author: Redacción El Comercio Perú
title: Donald Trump: Juez rechaza recurso del expresidente a multa de 83 millones de dólares por difamar a la escritora E. Jean Carroll | últimas | MUNDO | EL COMERCIO PERÚ
text: [1](/deporte-total/futbol-peruano/colo-colo-vs-alianza-lima-en-vivo-hoy-online-via-espn-premium-espn-star-plus-fox-sports-y-futbol-libre-tv-hora-del-partido-y-en-donde-se-puede-ver-partido-de-hoy-por-copa-libertadores-formaciones-pronostico-video-ch-noticia/) [Saber más](https://elcomercio.pe/buenas-practicas/) / NoticiasInformación basada en hechos y verificada de primera mano por el reportero, o reportada y verificada por fuentes expertas. | Informativo Un juez federal de [Nueva York](https://elcomercio.pe/noticias/nueva-york/) rechazó este jueves el recurso del expresidente [Donald Trump](https://elcomercio.pe/noticias/donald-trump/) para evitar la multa de más de 83 millones de dólares que está obligado a pagar por difamar a la escritora E. Jean Carroll. Trump había pagado una fianza de unos 91 millones para apelar la sentencia del juicio civil por difamación, determinado por un jurado, y pedir que se repitiera el proceso, pero el juez Lewis Kaplan denegó hoy la moción al considerarla “sin mérito”. MIRA AQUÍ: [Cómo una revista compraba historias negativas sobre Trump para que nunca fueran publicadas] La fianza permitió al expresidente evitar el pago de la multa el 11 de marzo mientras apelaba, y no está claro qué ocurrirá con los 91 millones, que supone un 110 % de la multa, ni cuánto tiempo tiene para pagarla. Esa causa, resuelta a finales de enero, fue la segunda contra Trump decidida a favor de Carroll después de que en mayo de 2023 un jurado ya condenara al exmandatario por “abuso sexual” contra ella en la década de 1990 y por difamación. MIRA AQUÍ: [Las polémicas frases que ponen a Trump cerca de ser declarado culpable de desacato] La pena económica de la segunda causa, de 83 millones por los daños y perjuicios de la difamación en la que incurrió Trump, fue mucho más abultada que la aplicada en la primera causa, de unos 5 millones, ligada al abuso sexual denunciado por la escritora. El dictamen de Kaplan de este jueves supone un nuevo revés para Donald Trump y sus finanzas, ya que afronta otra cuantiosa multa por el juicio por fraude contra su empresa, gastos para pagar la defensa de sus varios procesos en marcha y venideros, más los costes de su campaña presidencial. MIRA AQUÍ: [Biden bromea con que Trump se echó en el pelo la lejía que sugirió para combatir el coronavirus] El juez señaló que los “ataques” de Trump contra Carroll llegaron a 100 millones de personas (en alusión a quienes los leyeron o escucharon) y que el jurado concluyó legítimamente que este “hizo descarrilar la carrera, reputación y bienestar emocional” de una exitosa columnista y autora. Donald Trump afronta actualmente el primer juicio penal contra un expresidente en EE.UU., acusado de orquestar una trama para falsificar documentos financieros y silenciar una aventura con la actriz de cine para adultos [Stormy Daniels](https://elcomercio.pe/noticias/stormy-daniels/) que, en caso de hacerse pública, habría dañado su anterior campaña presidencial. author: Bérangère Bocquillon avec Guillaume Descours
title: Inquiétude pour la rentrée? Il manque des dizaines de directeurs d'école dans plusieurs départements
text:
INFO RMC. Selon nos informations, de très nombreux postes de directeurs et directrices d'écoles maternelles et élémentaires sont toujours vacants pour la rentrée prochaine. Aucun département sur le territoire n'est épargné. Le casse-tête des plannings pour la rentrée prochaine commence dans les écoles. La répartition des élèves dans les classes, des instituteurs aussi. Et pour mener tout ce petit monde, il y a les directrices et directeurs d'école (élémentaire ou maternelle). Le problème, c'est que l'Éducation nationale peine à recruter dans ce secteur. Selon nos informations, de nombreux postes sont toujours vacants.
Il manque, à l'issue des premières attributions de postes, 32 directeurs d’écoles élémentaires ou maternelles dans l’Essonne, 38 dans le Pas-de-Calais et 35 en Seine-et-Marne… Il manque aussi 21 directeurs ou directrices dans le Var, 23 en Seine-Saint-Denis, 13 dans la Somme, 9 dans le Morbihan, 8 en Loire-Atlantique. En réalité, aucun département sur le territoire n'est épargné.
Un manque d'attractivité? Il faut gérer la sécurité, les rencontres avec les familles, l’administratif, les absences des élèves et des enseignants. Hélène, directrice d’une école maternelle de six classes dans l’académie de Lyon, et membre du syndicat des directeurs d’école S2Dé, a frôlé le burn-out. Elle dispose d’à peine plus d’un jour par semaine pour la direction de l’école, le reste du temps, elle est devant ses élèves.
“J’ai l’impression de faire tout à moitié. J’ai l’impression qu’il y a aussi un changement d’attitude chez les familles dans l’agressivité, la façon dont on s’adresse à vous et c’est quelque chose qui m’affecte”, appuie-t-elle.
Rentrée scolaire: il manque déjà des directeurs et des directrices 1:04 Des efforts qui ne valent pas les 400 euros de plus? Elle travaille facilement 60 heures par semaine, calcule-t-elle et gère une équipe de 20 personnes entre enseignants et personnel. Et c’est beaucoup trop. "Je voulais bien faire et je ne m’arrêtais jamais. J’avais des témoignages de parents d'élèves qui me disaient qu’ils avaient vu que j’avais envoyé mon mail à minuit la veille. Tout ça moi, c’est terminé”, pointe-t-elle.
Hélène n’est pas la seule à renoncer à la direction d’école. Et si les rectorats n’ont pas assez de candidats, ils finiront par désigner des directeurs. Une solution qui n’en est pas une pour Guislaine David du syndicat SNUIPP d’enseignants du primaire.
“C’est très inquiétant. Comme l’école va mal, on demande toujours plus aux directrices et directeurs”, souligne-t-elle. Un directeur d’école, qui doit également enseigner, gagne environ 400 euros de plus par mois qu’un enseignant, une somme qui varie en fonction de la taille de l'école.
Bérangère Bocquillon avec Guillaume Descours

author: EdJenner
title: NYT Investigates Hamas’ Sexual Atrocities On October 7. The Evidence Is Horrifying.
text: Streaming Now The decade's most triggering comedy “Grandma, how did mom die?” After interviewing over 150 people and conducting a two-month investigation that included evidence from video footage and GPS data, The New York Times published a [report](https://www.nytimes.com/2023/12/28/world/middleeast/oct-7-attacks-hamas-israel-sexual-violence.html) about the sexual atrocities committed against Israeli women by Hamas on October 7, and the stories are shocking and horrific. The Times report highlights photographs showing a woman’s corpse with “dozens of nails driven into her thighs and groin,” as well as a video showing two dead Israeli women soldiers who were shot in their vaginas. One barbaric incident the Times documented involved a 24-year-old female accountant who was shot in the back and who hid under the low branches of a tree and covered herself in dry grass. She said she saw roughly 100 men arrive on motorcycles, cars, and trucks. The first victim she saw was a young woman with blood streaming down her back and her pants around her knees. The accountant said a man yanked the victim by the hair and forced her to bend over. Another man began raping her and every time she flinched he stabbed her in the back. The accountant said she witnessed another woman “shredded into pieces.” A Hamas terrorist raped her while another cut off one of her breasts with a box cutter. “One continues to rape her, and the other throws her breast to someone else, and they play with it, throw it, and it falls on the road,” she recalled, adding that the men sliced the victim’s face and then the woman fell from view. She said she saw terrorists carrying three severed heads of other women. The female accountant said she has become an insomniac, and when she does sleep she awakens covered in sweat. “That day, I became an animal,” she said. “I was emotionally detached, sharp, just the adrenaline of survival. I looked at all this as if I was photographing them with my eyes, not forgetting any detail. I told myself: I should remember everything.” Meanwhile, the United Nations Secretary-General, António Guterres, and the agency U.N. Women “did not acknowledge the many accusations until weeks after the attacks,” the Times noted. A young Israeli man said he saw five terrorists dragging a naked young woman. “They all gather around her,” he said. “She’s standing up. They start raping her. I saw the men standing in a half circle around her. One penetrates her. She screams. I still remember her voice, screams without words. Then one of them raises a knife and they just slaughtered her.” The first volunteer emergency medical technicians to arrive at the rave site, at which much of the massacre was committed, said they found dead women, no underwear and legs spread, with some of their hands tied with rope and zipties. A member of the rave’s production team whose two brothers were murdered in the massacre hid from the terrorists, later finding a woman naked from the waist down with her vagina area apparently sliced open. In Be’eri, a paramedic found two sisters, ages 16 and 13. One’s body had bruises on her groin; the other’s pajamas were pulled down and she had semen smeared on her back. A female dentist who worked at the identification center said she saw several dead women with cuts in their vaginas and another with fingernails pulled out. One young woman who was murdered was found with her face burned beyond recognition. Video of her body posted on October 8 went viral, the Times noted, “with thousands of people responding, desperate to know if the woman in the black dress was their missing friend, sister or daughter.” She was Gal Abdush, 34, a mother of two boys ages 10 and 7, whose husband, 35, was also murdered in the massacre. They had been in love since they were teenagers. Their grandmother has taken to lying in bed with the two boys until they fall asleep. The Times ends its report by noting that one night she tried to quietly slip out of the bedroom when the seven-year-old said, “Grandma, I want to ask you a question.” “Honey,” she said, “you can ask anything.” “Grandma, how did mom die?” the little girl asked.

author: Bill Desowitz
title: Jennifer Lee to Direct ‘Frozen 3’ and ‘4,’ Disney Names Jared Bush Head of Animation Studio
text:
Jennifer Lee , the co-director of the original “Frozen,” has stepped down as Disney Animation’s chief creative officer after six years and will exclusively return to filmmaking to direct the next two “Frozen” sequels. Lee will be succeeded in the role by filmmaker Jared Bush, co-writer and co-director of the Oscar-winning “Encanto” and “Zootopia,” and co-writer of “Moana,” Disney announced on Thursday.
Lee is currently writing and directing “Frozen 3,” which is set for release on November 24, 2027, and is also co-writing “Frozen 4” (with Marc Smith) while serving as executive producer. Bush currently serves as co-writer and executive producer of “Moana 2” (November 27) and writer and director of “Zootopia 2” (November 26, 2025). He’s also writing the live-action “Moana” movie (July 10, 2026).
Bush will report to Disney Entertainment Co-Chairman Alan Bergman, while Oscar-winning producer Clark Spencer (“Encanto,” “Zootopia”) continues as president, Walt Disney Animation Studios.
“Jared Bush is an incredible filmmaker and a talented executive who’s been a prominent creative force at Disney Animation for the past decade, and I am thrilled that he’ll be taking the reins of this storied studio,” Bergman said. “I also want to thank Jennifer Lee for her passionate leadership of the studio over the past several years — she’s made an indelible mark on both Disney Animation and the industry. I know she has so many more stories to tell, and there is truly no one better suited to oversee the continuation of the beloved story of ‘Frozen.’”
“I am so deeply grateful to Bob Iger and Alan Bergman for their faith in me, and thankful to Jennifer for her leadership and for her generous support as she embarks on the next chapters of ‘Frozen,’” said Bush. “Disney Animation is home to some of the greatest stories and characters of the past century, and I’m so excited to work with all of our filmmakers, artists, and Disney Animation team members as we shape the future of this legendary studio together.”
Added Lee: “I am so grateful to Bob and Alan for supporting my decision to return to filmmaking full time. Every day working with them is a master class in creativity, business, community, and integrity. I’ve always believed in Jared’s incredible talent and can’t wait to see, with his passion and dedication to animation, what he brings to the CCO role. For me, getting to collaborate with this studio of artists, animators, and storytellers is such a privilege, and I look forward to all we will create together.”
As CCO, Bush will oversee the creative output of the prestigious animation studio, including its films, series, and associated projects. Bush has been with the studio for more than a decade. He also served as executive producer for the Oscar-nominated “Raya and the Last Dragon,” and received an Emmy Award for “Zootopia+.” He additionally worked on “Frozen 2,” the Oscar winning “Big Hero 6,” and “Ralph Breaks the Internet.”
Lee is the Oscar-winning screenwriter and director behind “Frozen” and “Frozen 2,” two of the biggest animated hits of all time. Lee joined Disney in 2011 as co-writer of the Oscar-nominated “Wreck-It Ralph.” She was also an integral part of building the story for “Zootopia” and served as executive producer on “Encanto,” “Wish,” and “Raya and the Last Dragon,” as well as on the upcoming “Moana 2.”
Lee also oversaw Disney Animation’s first foray into animated series, including “Baymax,” the first-of-its-kind series “Iwájú,” and “Zootopia+,” for which she received an Emmy Award, and she is the Tony nominated writer of the book for the Broadway musical “Frozen.”
Lee, who succeeded the controversial John Lasseter as COO of Disney Animation , has been a funny, sharp-eyed, and compassionate writer and director. She expanded the Story Trust to include more writers and made sure that storyboarding occurred earlier in the process. Yet Lee was dogged by the box office failures of both the sci-adventure, “Strange World” (2022), and “Wish” (2023), the musical fantasy tribute to Disney’s 100th anniversary, with the performance of the latter film ($254 million worldwide) putting her on the hot seat.
To her credit, Lee also brought more women and cultural diversity into Disney’s animation ranks, which creatively drove the storytelling on “Raya and the Last Dragon,” “Encanto, and “Wish.” All three films contained modern, inclusive sensibilities for their female-driven stories, building on what Lee achieved with the ground-breaking “Frozen.”
For his part, Bush has proven to be a talented writer and director, evidenced by “Zootopia,” “Moana,” and “Encanto.” His animation background will be a major asset in his new role as COO, and he’s well liked among his colleagues. This should be a morale booster moving forward with his vision for continuing the Disney legacy with its own modern spin.

author: @WBAY
title: Several goats, pigs perish in Door County barn fire
text:
Several goats, pigs perish in Door County barn fire
BRUSSELS, Wis. (WBAY) - Several animals, including five goats and six pigs, perished in a barn fire in Brussels on Tuesday evening.
The Brussels-Union-Gardner (BUG) Fire Department responded around 4:48 p.m. Tuesday for a structure fire on Star Road. Calls to 911 indicated a barn was fully engulfed with animals still inside.
When crews arrived on scene, the department said they found the west end of the barn was fully engulfed with smoke pouring out the entire structure. A home was approximately 50 feet from the barn. Property owners were on scene trying to get animals out of the barn.
First responders were able to rescue some full size pigs and three piglets from the east end of the barn before the barn became fully engulfed from one end to the other. Firefighters were also able to rescue approximately 30 chickens and secured them in another structure on site.
Crews were able to knock down the flames in around 30 to 40 minutes.
Due to a metal roof collapsing during fire suppression efforts, the department said an excavator responded to the scene to remove the metal roof so firefighters could fully extinguish the flames.
The department said the fire appeared to have started on the west end of the barn, where the property owners said they had two heat lamps used to keep baby goats warm.
The property owner did not have insurance on the barn, which was built in 1940 and was approximately 100 feet by 40 feet in size. The home sustained heat damage to the exterior vinyl siding.
Five goats and six pigs were among the several animals who perished in the fire, according to the department. The cause of the fire is undetermined at this time, but given initial information and first on scene reports, the department said the fire does not appear to be suspicious.
Two water supply fill sites were set up at BUG Fire Station 1 located on County C. BUG Fire responded with 10 units and 29 Firefighters. The incident was cleared at 9:01 pm.
The following agencies assisted: Fire Departments of Southern Door, Nasewaupee, Sturgeon Bay, Casco, New Franken, Algoma, Jacksonport, Kewaunee, Sister Bay Liberty Grove, Egg Harbor, Tisch Mills, Denmark, Carlton and Luxemburg. Also assisting were Door County EMS, Door County Sheriff’s Office, Wisconsin Public Service and Door County 911 Communications Center.
“We extend our heartfelt thoughts to the property owners for their loss,” the department said in a statement.
